entry.title: Message Handlers on Web API vs. MVC

link.title: Message Handlers on Web API vs. MVC

entry.content:
If you were wondering, have a look at this auth0 sample code snippet on asp.net. It uses MessageHandlers to wire access token validation. I tried to do the same with an MVC web app but had hard luck :-1: getting it to work, and here’s why it is was a terrible idea.

MessageHandlers are part of the Web API Pipeline and won’t work with MVC web apps. Also, there were some considerable differences between the two kinds of controllers, one meant to serve views and the other meant to serve data. The Content Negotiation Algorithm (Conneg) in the ASP.NET stack is a good source of information regarding how request/response were acknowledged based on Accept header and the Content-Type.

And for the MVC web apps, a possible fix, or rather an alternative to MessageHandlers was to write a Custom Action Filter, otherwise move the backend API endpoints to a Web API within the MVC app.
entry.summary: Message Handlers are best for implementing cross-cutting concerns, but they are part of Web API Pipeline and not for MVC web apps. Use Action Filters instead.

entry.title: Hello world :wave:
entry.content:
Here’s why I gave up all those wide spread of productivity and notes taking apps from Evernote to Onenote, Workflowy, Trello, Todoist, and even Notion. They are all great apps, but it makes more sense, at least for me, to use GitHub since I interact with it daily, so why not use it for everything else. GitHub used to be my unicorn, and now it is my bitch. Just a personal preference, with :heart: of course.

In case you were wondering, this site is:

  • :lock: Designed from the Otto Theme
  • Coded with VS Code
  • Built on Jekyll Docker
  • Published with GitHub Actions for GitHub Pages, and
  • Hosted on GitHub Pages

And, this article amongst rest are written in Markdown with Paper app.

For starters, you want to have a look at Docsify. It is a documentation site generator with a great community support. Awesome Docsify is a good source of information. I played around a bit with Docsify and wrote a plugin or two as well for my needs, but that was before I picked Jekyll and it’s still a work in-progress.
entry.summary: Just an intro post on the tech stack and some alternatives I tried out before GitHub became my bitch.
